Pama, charged with manslaughter, was granted conditional bail requiring passport surrender, a nightly curfew, and police check-ins, with his case adjourned until May 18.

Yulia Simonova, a 52-year-old music teacher, faces 15 years in prison for attempting to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old former pupil, Damian Vanya, after he ended their relationship for a classmate. Police conducted a sting operation in Shatura, Russia, deploying an undercover officer posing as a hitman, who recorded Simonova detailing her demands—including breaking the boy’s limbs, causing him to bleed out, and participating in his final moments—for 100,000 rubles (£1,400). After she paid partial expenses, armed police arrested her, charging her with attempted murder, while Vanya expressed relief and hoped for a lifelong sentence.

Chelsea manager José Mourinho, a devout Catholic, prays daily for personal matters but never about football, maintaining strict separation between his professional and family life. The father-of-two, alongside his wife Matilde Faria, supports the World Food Programme as an ambassador against hunger, grounded by his family's awareness of poverty. Despite his confrontational managerial persona, Mourinho asserts he is a good person who aids others, though acknowledges mistakes in his high-pressure career. Fined £25,000 earlier in the season for alleging a media campaign against Chelsea, he currently leads the league while emphasizing his private faith and family priorities, including attending events like the Hunger Games premiere with his children.

Bob Barker, the 91-year-old former host of "The Price is Right" who retired in 2007 after 35 years, returned to host the show's April 1 edition for the first time in eight years, overseeing the "Lucky Seven" game before handing duties back to current host Drew Carey.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington D.C. on Friday morning for alleged attempted burglary and destruction of property at a residence on the 3200 block of D Street SE. The Metropolitan Police took him into custody around 12:30 a.m., and his agency revoked his security clearance and placed him on leave. Assigned to the Foreign Missions Branch, which handles U.S. diplomatic activities under the State Department, Baldwin was scheduled for arraignment later that day without listed legal representation. His arrest follows unrelated allegations of misconduct against a high-ranking supervisor within the agency, both incidents adding to recent scrutiny over the Secret Service’s conduct, including a separate March investigation into officials accused of breaching White House security after drinking.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed risked his life to photograph a hungry male lion in Lahore's safari park, leaving his car to creep within 10 feet of the animal while lying on the ground. The camera's shutter sound alerted the lion, forcing Saeed to retreat rapidly as the lion aggressively charged, though he narrowly escaped back into his vehicle. Reflecting on the encounter, Saeed acknowledged the extreme danger, stating he would not attempt it again despite initially laughing off the incident.

New York City police released an image of a heart-shaped tattoo with the name "Monique" to help identify an unnamed woman found unconscious and later pronounced dead on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Brooklyn’s Gravesend section. The woman, estimated to be between 25 and 45 years old, had no identification but bore the distinctive, faded tattoo on her right leg, which investigators believe depicts a ribbon with the name "Monique" inside a heart topped with a rose. Authorities are awaiting a medical examiner’s report to determine her cause of death and urge anyone with information to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers at 800-577-TIPS.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a solar-powered, two-bedroom home on a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK in 2009, as they couldn’t afford traditional property. Over a year and a half, they constructed the wood-and-steel dwelling with a steel frame, wood-fired stove, stained glass windows, and solar panels, achieving near self-sufficiency with water from a nearby spring and minimal electricity costs. The home, situated on a Nelson lot surrounded by nature, cost approximately $25,000, reflecting their desire for a cozy, affordable, and environmentally conscious living space.

Research indicates that children who share iPads in class achieve significantly higher scores in early literacy tests compared to those using devices individually or not at all, contradicting skepticism about technology in non-IT classrooms. A Northwestern University study involving 352 kindergarten students found shared-device users outscored peers by approximately 30 points, attributing the success to collaborative learning dynamics rather than technology alone. The researcher suggests schools should reevaluate tablet usage strategies, particularly in early grades, to maximize educational effectiveness, with findings presented at an international conference in Puerto Rico.

A two-legged piglet born without hind legs has gained internet fame after a video showcased its ability to balance and walk on its front trotters, despite initially unsteady steps. Owned by farmer Ms. Duan in Qionglai City, Sichuan Province, China, the piglet—nicknamed "Super Pig"—has drawn local villagers and online attention for its resilience, while its siblings, born with all four legs, occasionally mimic its stance. The phenomenon echoes a similar case of a two-legged rabbit in Liuzhou Zoo, highlighting unusual animal adaptability capturing public interest.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, Dayle Coyne Racing pit crew member Todd Phillips was injured when driver Francesco Dracone spun exiting his pit box on lap 25, striking Phillips' leg with his car. Phillips, a front-outside tire changer, received stitches for a leg cut at the infield care center and was released. Rainy conditions prior to the race caused traction issues for multiple drivers, while Dracone ultimately failed to finish, placing 23rd after spinning again later in the event.

Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, brutally murdered his dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena (stage name Amanda Bueno), 29, in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, by smashing her head into concrete 11 times and shooting her in the face five times after accusing her of being unfaithful. He confessed the attack was driven by jealousy over men looking at her, with CCTV footage and neighbor testimony confirming the assault, preceding arguments, and his attempt to flee using a stolen car containing multiple weapons. Severiano faces life imprisonment.

Sarah Wilson, journalist and author of *I Quit Sugar*, revealed her battle with mental illness, detailing how severe anxiety, compounded by stress, thyroid disease, and familial distance, led her to contemplate suicide, feeling "no existential point in continuing" and isolated due to lacking a partner or children. She emphasizes the interconnectedness of depression and anxiety, advocating for recognizing this link to address rising rates among Australian women, while noting anxiety is becoming as prevalent as depression, with statistics showing one in three women experiencing it. Wilson now accepts her identity as an "anxious person" and stresses the need for societal acknowledgment to combat these issues.

Elena Curtin, a seven-months-pregnant Oregon woman, faced second-degree assault charges after striking her boyfriend’s ex-girlfriend in the head and arm with a crowbar in November 2014, when she found the woman using heroin in her bathroom and refusing to leave. Prosecutors dropped the charges in 2016, deeming Curtin’s actions justified under Oregon law, which permits force against intruders who won’t depart. The ex-girlfriend, described as jealous and harassing Curtin for years, had a history of enabling the boyfriend’s heroin addiction and shared a child with him. Curtin, who gave birth in January 2015, has since left the relationship and moved in with her parents, while the boyfriend remains absent from their child’s life.

Gemma, a pit bull in California, was filmed reacting with disgust after her owner mixed a broccoli spear with her treats, prompting her to spit it out; her family hopes the two children she lives with do not emulate her aversion to vegetables. Beyond this incident, Gemma is shown enjoying activities like sleeping and spending time with her human family.

HSBC apologized after a link on its official website erroneously directed visitors to a pornographic site, which had taken over the expired domain of its discontinued Young Entrepreneur Awards page following the program's cancellation in 2011. The bank removed the hyperlink upon discovering the error, denied any affiliation with the external site, and emphasized its website's security, while publicly apologizing for the inconvenience caused.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy, Marcus, helped rescue himself and his 9-year-old sister, Aaliyah, during a house fire in Clinton by calmly calling 911, providing detailed directions to firefighters, and reassuring his sister after she panicked. Trapped in a second-floor bedroom as the fire spread from the first floor, Marcus guided firefighters through the home’s layout during an 11-minute call, leading to their rescue via a broken window. Firefighter Lt. Kenny Ward handed Marcus to another rescuer and gave his gas mask to Aaliyah, who was treated alongside her brother for non-life-threatening injuries. Three other family members escaped independently and were hospitalized separately.

Bioluminescent algae caused by the phytoplankton *Noctiluca scintillans* illuminated Australia's east coast, particularly in Jervis Bay, New South Wales, creating a vivid neon glow described by photographer Andy Hutchinson as a "beautiful supernatural scene." The phenomenon, also observed at Sydney's Manly Beach in 2014, occurs naturally during spring and autumn when the carnivorous single-celled organisms emit light as a defense mechanism while preying on diatoms, with expert Iain Suthers confirming it is typically harmless.

New genetic tests, such as Endopredict, analyze tumor markers to assess breast cancer recurrence risk post-surgery, enabling some patients to avoid chemotherapy if their risk is determined to be low (e.g., 5% or less). These tests, currently costly and primarily available privately, could reduce reliance on chemotherapy—a treatment with severe side effects often prescribed preemptively to most patients—while experts advocate for NHS adoption due to potential long-term cost savings. Patient cases highlight how results alleviate chemotherapy fears and empower informed decisions, though accessibility remains a challenge.

Over 25 pregnant Royal Navy personnel have been airlifted from ships since 2006, including five from HMS Ocean and one from HMS Illustrious ("HMS Lusty"), with 18 other vessels reporting similar evacuations, despite a strict "no touching" rule implying conceptions occurred pre-deployment or during leave. This follows the 2014 removal of Commander Sarah West, the Navy’s first female warship captain, over alleged misconduct, and highlights ongoing challenges since women began serving at sea in 1990, with 9% of personnel now female. Additionally, nearly 100 pregnant British servicewomen were evacuated from Afghanistan (2006–2013) and 102 from Iraq due to rules banning expectant mothers from war zones, though some conceptions likely occurred pre-deployment. Military policy mandates immediate repatriation for pregnant personnel, utilizing medical evacuation flights.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive cesium was discovered on the roof of Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s residence, raising terrorism concerns amid a court’s approval to restart nuclear reactors at the Sendai plant, a decision opposed by many due to safety fears following the 2011 Fukushima disaster. The drone, equipped with a camera, smoke flares, and a bottle containing non-lethal levels of cesium, prompted investigations into its origin and warnings from officials about potential drone-related threats at future events like the Olympics or G7 summit. Despite existing restrictions near airports, Tokyo lacks flight regulations for drones over government buildings, highlighting security gaps as authorities pledge to address the risk.

Lu Xincai, a security guard from Zhejiang Province in China, takes his 84-year-old mother, who suffers from Alzheimer’s disease, to work with him daily on his motorbike due to fears she might get lost if left alone, as she previously wandered off after his father’s death. He secures her with a sash during their hour-long commute and ensures her safety at his workplace, where his employer provides a private room. His devotion stems from gratitude for her lifelong care, symbolized by his statement, “I was an apple in my mum’s eye, and now she’s my apple,” reflecting his duty to protect her in her vulnerability.

A major study published in the American Journal of Public Health found that heavy drinking among Americans increased by 17.2% between 2005 and 2012, driven largely by rising rates among women due to shifting social norms. Binge drinking also surged, with women’s rates increasing over seven times faster than men’s nationwide, exemplified by a 36% spike in Santa Clara County, California. In 2012, 8% of Americans were heavy drinkers (exceeding one drink/day for women, two for men) and 18% were binge drinkers (four-plus drinks for women, five-plus for men). The study linked these trends to cultural shifts, economic factors like cheaper alcohol and aggressive advertising, weakened alcohol policies, and demographic changes in affluent urban areas. Despite stable overall drinking rates, alcohol-related deaths totaled 88,600 in 2010, with excessive drinking costing over $220 billion annually, while treatment centers reported rising admissions yet persistent barriers to care.

UN officials warn that doctors are jeopardizing women and infants' health by performing caesarean sections too frequently, emphasizing the procedure should only be conducted when medically necessary due to risks of infection, complications, or death. While over 25% of births in England now involve caesareans—more than double since the 1990s—the World Health Organization (WHO) states the ideal rate is 10-15%, citing unnecessary procedures driven by maternal anxiety, prior complicated births, or age-related factors. WHO criticizes current NHS guidelines, which permit caesareans without medical justification, noting they divert resources and cost significantly more (£2,369 vs. £1,665 for natural births), while prior research indicates up to 10% of cases result in infections.

Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham, was arrested on April 17 after breaking into an $800,000 Edgartown summer home owned by Mark Conklin, living there for at least a week, and selling stolen items in a yard sale. Conklin discovered Filkins in his living room; she falsely claimed ownership and fled when police were called, but was recaptured hours later after returning to the property. Police found a broken window covered by a blanket and charged her with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. Stolen items included high-value furniture, a grill, lamps, linens, and a painting, with authorities urging anyone who purchased goods to return them for restitution. Filkins is scheduled for a May 14 court appearance.

Bella Crooke's lost iPhone was returned after Albury police officers, who found the unlocked device, posted humorous selfies and puns on her Facebook page to locate her, including jokes about the phone being in a "holding cell" and needing her to "post bail." The phone, lost at a friend's party, was handed in by a security guard, and officers used social media to contact Bella, who reclaimed it after being recognized from her profile without needing to provide her name. The creative approach drew praise from her friends, and Bella later added a password to her phone, appreciating the police's humor and efforts.

A five-day-old hippopotamus calf was fatally injured in Isimangaliso Wetland Park, South Africa, after being caught in a fight between two adult male hippos. The calf’s mother, who had initially shielded it from younger hippos, watched helplessly as one male seized the calf, flung it into the air, and dragged it through the water. Despite the mother’s attempts to intervene, the calf died hours later from its injuries. Tour operator Stacey Farrell witnessed the incident, noting the attackers’ motives—whether aggression, play, or jealousy—remained unclear.

A three-bedroom apartment in London's exclusive Knightsbridge area is listed at £575,000—far below neighboring prices—due to its remaining three-year lease, making it effectively a short-term rental costing £15,000 monthly, though requiring renovation. If the lease is extended (likely costing £3.35–4.5 million for 90 years), the property’s value could surge to over £6 million, given its prime location, spacious layout, and potential post-renovation value. Estate agents highlight the rarity of such opportunities in the area, attracting interest from developers and investors, but warn of significant costs to secure a long-term lease, with experts advising caution to avoid losing value as the lease expires.

A computer outage disrupted sales registers at 8,000 Starbucks stores across the U.S. and Canada on Friday, forcing early closures at some locations while others gave away free drinks and food, prompting widespread social media buzz from customers. The company attributed the issue to a failed daily system refresh, apologized for the inconvenience, and confirmed operations would resume normally by Saturday. The incident occurred just one day after Starbucks reported record quarterly earnings of $4.6 billion, with shares rising 4.4% prior to the outage.

Terrorists are using rural areas in West Wales, including Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, for radicalization and training, according to a Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit officer. Detective Constable Gareth Jones warned that individuals engage in ordinary community activities while harboring hidden extremist motives, noting such threats are not limited to cities. Historical cases include a 1998 incident where Abu Hamza sent extremists to train in the Brecon Beacons, the 2005 presence of two 7/7 bombers in North Wales, a 2010 Al-Qaeda-inspired plot by Cardiff-based terrorists, and Michael Adebowale—convicted in the Lee Rigby murder—studying at a now-closed institute in Wales linked to Iraqi clerics. Jones stressed the importance of community vigilance in identifying these activities.

A species of whale feared to be extinct, the Omura's whale, was found washed ashore on a remote West Australian beach in Exmouth after Tropical Cyclone Olwyn, marking the first confirmed sighting in Western Australia and only the second in Australia. Initially unidentified due to its rarity, DNA testing confirmed the 5.68-meter juvenile female as an Omura's whale, a species first scientifically described in 2003 and typically inhabiting tropical waters near Indonesia, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The discovery provides critical insights into the species' biology, including unique skeletal features like 53 vertebrae, with plans to recover the skeleton for further research and potential museum display. Environment Minister Albert Jacob emphasized the find's significance for advancing scientific understanding of the whale's distribution and characteristics.

The passage critiques Cheryl Rios' argument that Hillary Clinton is unfit for the presidency due to female hormones causing irrationality, countering that male hormones have historically driven poor leadership decisions and studies show women take fewer risks. It highlights Rios' biblical and hormonal claims as reflective of broader gender bias against women in leadership, despite evidence that equality benefits society economically and socially. The text underscores systemic discrimination—such as corporate board gender disparities and stereotypes in academia—and argues that bias, not biology, limits women's potential, urging a focus on dismantling stereotypes to empower female candidates like Clinton, who face steeper electoral challenges due to ingrained prejudice.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, known for roles in *All Creatures Great and Small* and portrayals of Winston Churchill, is auctioning over 200 antiques valued at £100,000 to downsize his home. The collection, amassed due to his interests in military history and literature, includes a 3D diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, Victorian furniture, a longbow, and a portrait of Hardy, alongside books, swords, and chandeliers. Highlighted items like the diorama and furniture are estimated to fetch up to £6,000 and £4,000, respectively. An expert on medieval longbows and a former student of J.R.R. Tolkien, Hardy expressed sadness over parting with his treasures but hopes buyers will cherish them. The auction, held by Dominic Winter in Gloucestershire, also reflects his career spanning Shakespearean theater, collaborations with Laurence Olivier and Judi Dench, and later roles in *Harry Potter* as Cornelius Fudge.

Michael Scott Shemansky is a fugitive murder suspect wanted in Florida for killing his mother, Sandra Shemansky, 57, whose body was discovered during a well-being check at their shared home after he missed a court-ordered supervised visit with his son. Authorities confirmed foul play, recovered the murder weapon, and noted Shemansky’s history of mental illness, including bipolar disorder and involuntary psychiatric commitment, alongside a parole status for battery and a prior domestic violence injunction from his estranged wife. Neighbors suggested divorce-related stress and his mother’s alleged interference in the visitation triggered the violence, citing recent unfavorable legal paperwork. Shemansky, last seen fleeing without supplies or medication, remains at large, prompting his wife to prepare for potential confrontation, while police urge tips at 407-656-3636.

Eugene, Oregon, has been awarded the right to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships after the International Association of Athletics Federations Council bypassed the standard bidding process, citing a "unique strategic opportunity" to stage the event in the United States for the first time. This decision followed Eugene's failed 2019 bid, which was won by Doha, Qatar, and came after a persuasive presentation demonstrated the city's readiness. IAAF President Lamine Diack justified the move as a chance to leverage partnerships across public, private, and media sectors while expanding the sport's global reach, noting a similar non-bid award for the 2007 Osaka championships.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model and care assistant, was jailed for 16 years for manslaughter after luring professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56, to his death in a plotted robbery. Granger targeted Hassan at a London casino, feigning a relationship to exploit his wealth, before leaving his flat door unlocked for her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson and accomplice Nicholas Chandler, who brutally beat and killed him while searching for hidden gambling winnings. The attackers left Hassan bound and bloodied, with multiple broken bones, stealing cash and valuables. Jackson and Chandler received life sentences for murder, while Granger’s lesser conviction stemmed from her role in enabling the attack, despite claims she acted under Jackson’s influence. The judge condemned the "pitiless and wicked" assault, emphasizing Granger’s deceit, while Hassan’s family expressed enduring grief over his violent death.

Cesc Fàbregas's recent performances have highlighted a recurring post-Christmas slump, with the Chelsea midfielder struggling in Spain's 2-0 defeat to Holland and failing to maintain his early-season form, which had positioned him to challenge Thierry Henry's Premier League assist record. Despite a strong start that yielded 15 assists by mid-January, his productivity has plummeted to just one assist in five subsequent league games and four in 15 appearances in 2015, echoing Barcelona's past observations about his late-season decline. While Chelsea remains in contention for the Premier League title, Fàbregas's fatigue and diminished impact have raised concerns, though upcoming fixtures against teams he previously dominated offer an opportunity to regain form and secure both personal accolades and the league championship.

West Ham are in discussions to sign 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford from Montego Bay United after he impressed during a two-week trial with their academy, despite competing interest from Belgian clubs. The club has also announced affordable season ticket prices starting at £289 for the Olympic Stadium, aiming to offer the Premier League's cheapest rates to fill the 54,000-seat venue upon their 2016-17 relocation.

Police have discontinued their investigation into a January assault on Mike Lane, a 40-year-old huntsman and joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, despite substantial evidence including a video, suspect names, and vehicle registrations provided to Wiltshire Police. Lane, hospitalized with concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss after being beaten and kicked by balaclava-clad protesters wielding iron bars, condemned the decision as "pathetic," criticizing police efforts. The attack occurred during a legal trail hunt using an artificial scent, with protesters disrupting hounds using citronella spray. Witnesses described the assailants as aggressive, and while police released a suspect's image, no arrests were made. Hunt supporters and allies expressed outrage, citing rural crime neglect and advocating for a ban on saboteur face coverings. Police stated the case is suspended pending further evidence but remains open for potential reopening.

The White House announced that Adam Gadahn, a 36-year-old American-born al Qaeda propagandist known for anti-U.S. statements and threats, was killed in a January counterterrorism operation, alongside another U.S. citizen, Ahmed Farouq, in a separate strike that also inadvertently killed hostages Warren Weinstein and Giovanni Lo Porto. Gadahn, raised in California and converted to Islam in 1995, joined al Qaeda in 1998, becoming a prominent English-language spokesperson who appeared in videos threatening attacks, criticizing U.S. policies and leaders, urging lone-wolf assaults, and advocating for regime change in Muslim-majority nations, while also addressing his Jewish heritage and renouncing his U.S. citizenship. Indicted for treason in 2006 and listed among the FBI’s most wanted terrorists, he played a key role in the group’s media strategy, as evidenced by a 2011 letter to Osama bin Laden, and remained active until his final video in 2014 calling for uprisings in Saudi Arabia and Pakistan.

A viral video in China showcases five-year-old Mai Zizhuo, a basketball prodigy who began playing at two and a half, demonstrating advanced skills like dribbling two balls and scoring consecutively, which has garnered widespread admiration and disbelief online, drawing comparisons to NBA star Yao Ming and sparking awe among viewers who praise his talent while humorously lamenting their own abilities.

Tom O'Carroll, a former key activist for the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), which campaigned to legalise child sex in the 1970s and 1980s, has become a supporter of Hacked Off, a media pressure group advocating for state regulation of the press following the phone-hacking scandal. O'Carroll, who was jailed in 1981 for "corrupting public morals" and previously associated with the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL), attended a Hacked Off rally in Parliament in February 2025 to lobby MPs for statutory press oversight, as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. His involvement, confirmed via a blog post about the event chaired by comedian John Cleese, has caused embarrassment for Hacked Off, which opposes the Independent Press Standards Organisation and emphasizes its open public meetings.

The Icebergs Club pool at Bondi Beach was temporarily drained to host an unconventional catwalk for Ten Pieces' presentation during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia, displacing regular swimmers. Models showcased the brand's monochrome, unisex capsule collection—designed by restaurateur Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss—on a unique runway through the empty pool and along the oceanfront break wall. The ten-piece line, intended to be styled in 20 versatile ways for day-to-night wear, was presented under sunny skies to crowds gathered on the club's balcony and passers-by, with guests enjoying Icebergs catering and minimalist, androgynous designs against a striking ocean backdrop.

Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan visited Six Flags Discovery Kingdom in Northern California with his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa, where he posed with and fed a rare white tiger, giraffes, and sea lions. The family outing followed Khan’s recent announcement confirming his next fight against former light-welterweight champion Chris Algieri on May 30, dismissing speculation about facing British rival Kell Brook or other contenders like Adrien Broner and Keith Thurman.

The name of Mohammed Abu Khdeir, a Palestinian teenager killed by Israeli perpetrators in 2014, will be removed from Israel’s national memorial wall at Mount Herzl after his family and the victims’ advocacy group Almagor objected to his inclusion. Abu Khdeir’s father criticized the lack of consent and rejected associating his son’s name with Israeli soldiers, while Almagor argued the murder was a criminal act, not terrorism. Following pressure from Almagor and the family, the National Insurance Institute of Israel agreed to remove the name from both the physical memorial and its website, with legal proceedings against the suspects ongoing.

A California-based YouTube user, Lionel Hutz, filmed his young son persistently chasing the family cat in their garden to use the feline’s belly as a pillow. Footage shows the boy repeatedly plopping onto the cat mid-grooming, only for the annoyed pet to immediately flee, prompting the child to follow and try again. After multiple attempts, the cat abandons the game and retreats indoors, though a later video depicts the pair reconciling as the boy feeds the cat treats.

A police corruption trial in Philadelphia involves testimony from Robert Kushner, a former marijuana dealer and varsity coach, who was fired from the Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after revealing his criminal past during the trial. Kushner, one of over a dozen ex-dealers testifying for the prosecution, accused six former drug squad officers of stealing cash and drugs from him during a 2007 arrest, though his own record includes expunged charges, a 2011 arrest, and a 2008 DUI conviction. The school, unaware of his history despite a background check, terminated him, while Kushner maintains he reformed and did not intend to deceive. Defense attorneys argue the case relies on unreliable witnesses, including 19 drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop, as the officers face charges of racketeering, extortion, and robbery.

An explosion at a paraxylene (PX) chemical plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian province, injured six people, triggered a large fire, and prompted a response by over 600 firefighters, who later controlled the blaze. The Monday night blast, caused by an oil leak at a storage facility, did not result in a toxic spill, though residents reported hearing the explosion and feeling tremors. Five injuries were from broken glass, and the plant—previously relocated from Xiamen in 2007 due to pollution protests—has faced prior incidents, including a 2013 explosion with no casualties. Public opposition to PX facilities in China, despite demonstration bans, has led to violent protests in recent years over health and environmental risks.

Aston Villa's Jack Grealish defiantly maintains his superstition of wearing low socks and children's shin pads despite referees' warnings, attributing this habit to lifelong practice and noting it has prevented shin injuries. He marked his first Premier League start in a 3-3 draw against QPR, acknowledging the game's difficulty but expressing gratitude for the manager's trust and hoping for more opportunities before the season ends.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has suffered irreversible brain damage and remains unresponsive despite emerging from a medically induced coma, according to her grandmother Cissy Houston, who noted she may live in this condition long-term. While a family source confirmed her unchanged neurological state for three months, with no response to stimuli and a tracheostomy in place, her father Bobby Brown and his wife claimed she had improved, opened her eyes, and begun rehabilitation. The family attorney acknowledged gradual progress but emphasized her future quality of life remains uncertain, with rehabilitation expected to be lengthy and outcomes unclear for years.

Russia secured a 2-0 lead in their Fed Cup tie against Germany, moving closer to the final, after Svetlana Kuznetsova defeated Julia Goerges in straight sets and Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point to beat Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3. Pavlyuchenkova overcame Lisicki’s powerful play and 13 double faults of her own, while Lisicki’s 63 unforced errors proved costly. Russia now needs one more win from Sunday’s matches to reach the final and pursue their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales, still recovering from last week's severe storms and flooding, are warned of another east coast low system expected to bring heavy rain and strong winds from Thursday through Saturday, potentially exacerbating damage in already saturated areas like the hard-hit Hunter Region. The State Emergency Service (SES), grappling with over 4,000 outstanding jobs from 24,196 requests, expresses concern that renewed storms will hinder cleanup efforts, particularly in regions with uprooted trees and flood-prone ground. Meteorologists note the system may be less intense than last week's but caution coastal areas, especially the northeast, face significant rainfall, while the SES urges communities to prepare homes and families to mitigate further devastation.

Nina Moric, a model known for appearing in Ricky Martin’s “La Vida Loca” video, denied Italian media reports claiming she attempted suicide, instead attributing her hospitalization to a collapse caused by low blood pressure and a domestic accident where she hit her head. She shared photos of her injuries on Instagram, reassuring her 40,000 followers she was recovering at home and criticized media speculation, including her boyfriend’s initial confirmation of the suicide attempt, which she dismissed as false. Reports also referenced a past 2009 overdose allegation and highlighted her tumultuous history with ex-husband Fabrizio Corona, a jailed paparazzo convicted of blackmailing celebrities, though she now focuses on her recovery and personal life.

As Kate and William await their second child, a YouGov poll reveals that 12% of Britons favor naming a daughter Diana, after William’s late mother, with Alice and Charlotte (honoring the Queen’s aunt and Prince Charles) following at 9% each. For a boy, James (13%) and Alexander are preferred, though 25% of the 2,200 polled hope for a girl, compared to 3% wanting a brother for Prince George. Social media users echo support for "Diana," while 68% approve of William’s six-week paternity leave.

A suicide bomber attacked protesters in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, killing 17 people and wounding 64, including a lawmaker, as they marched to a larger rally against the provincial governor. The Taliban denied involvement, and no other group claimed responsibility for the 10 a.m. local time attack.

Dani Alves will depart Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer, ending seven trophy-laden years that included four La Liga titles and two Champions League wins. The 31-year-old's agent and ex-wife, Dinorah Santana, confirmed he declined a three-year extension contingent on him playing 60% of matches, criticizing Barcelona for delaying renewal talks until April and declaring negotiations conclusively over.

Pablo Osvaldo, currently on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton, has called for Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentine club, citing their South American-style flair and belief they would thrive at La Bombonera, where fans would idolize them. The 29-year-old striker, who has scored three goals in six games for Boca, emphasizes the duo's world-class abilities and his conviction that they would be perfect additions to the team, despite acknowledging Totti's iconic status at Roma and Pirlo's global midfield reputation.

Amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson, 18, suffered a dramatic double somersault fall from his horse Merrion Square at Wincanton, which went viral online, yet sustained only a minor nose injury. Despite the spectacle, he resumed stable duties and riding without hesitation, downplaying the incident as a blur until he reviewed the footage with concerned peers. Ferguson faced lighthearted teasing and gained social media followers, humorously suggesting a future in gymnastics due to his acrobatic dismount.

The release of *Avengers: Age of Ultron* prompted London Wasps rugby captain James Haskell to share an Instagram photo of himself dressed as Iron Man, referencing the film's premiere in London. A flanker with 57 England caps, Haskell returned to Wasps in 2012 after playing for Stade Français (France), Ricoh Black Rams (Japan), and Highlanders (New Zealand), having initially joined the club in 2002 and later surpassing 100 appearances for them since his comeback.

The wide-leg trouser emerges as a key SS15 trend, offering an effortless alternative to skinny jeans with styles ranging from denim and cropped to printed or striped designs. Endorsed by figures like Louise Redknapp, the look balances retro appeal (reminiscent of 1970s comebacks) with modern versatility, though styling requires careful proportion—pairing high heels, simple tops, and high-waisted cuts to elongate the silhouette, particularly for shorter wearers. Denim iterations lead the trend, showcased by Gucci and Topshop’s 1970s-inspired Miller jean, while brands like Celine and Stella McCartney offer dressier options. Accessible alternatives are noted via labels like Finery London, emphasizing the trend’s adaptability across seasons and occasions, with additional inspiration available at astylealbum.com.

The University of Michigan reversed its decision to cancel a campus screening of "American Sniper" after initially yielding to student objections that the film negatively portrays the Middle East, prompting a counter-petition and backlash. Citing commitment to freedom of expression, the university's vice president acknowledged the cancellation was a mistake, allowing the screening to proceed as part of the UMIX student event series while offering "Paddington" as an alternative for those opposed. The film, which depicts the life of Navy SEAL Chris Kyle and earned Bradley Cooper an Oscar nomination, had faced criticism from over 200 students in a region with the nation's largest Arab-American population, though the reversal drew praise from the university's football coach.

Two French tourists were charged with animal cruelty after attempting to set a quokka on fire using an aerosol spray and lighter on Rottnest Island, Western Australia, on April 3. The quokka survived but was singed, while detectives seized video evidence and evicted the men, aged 18 and 24, from the island. They will face court in Fremantle on April 17, with quokkas noted as cat-sized marsupials inhabiting islands off Western Australia’s coast.

102-year-old former dancer Alice Barker, who performed in 1930s-40s New York venues like the Cotton Club alongside stars such as Bill "Bojangles" Robinson and Frank Sinatra, finally saw herself dance for the first time after decades of lost footage and memorabilia. Film historian Mark Cantor and volunteers compiled rare "soundies" (early music videos) featuring Barker, screened them at her nursing home, prompting her delighted response: "It's just fabulous."

A recent study by vehicle leasing firm OSV reveals a decline in Britons washing their own cars, with 31% of men and 75% of women admitting they never do so, citing factors like Sunday shopping, live sports, the rise of affordable hand car washes, and larger vehicles. While 15 million cars were cleaned during the Easter holiday, often as an excuse to leave home, regional data shows higher owner-washing rates in Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield, and lower rates in Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh. Audi, Toyota, and BMW owners wash their cars most frequently, while Range Rover, Peugeot, and Mercedes owners do so least often, reflecting broader shifts away from the tradition due to time constraints, convenience, and cost-effective alternatives.

Martin Skrtel acknowledges Steven Gerrard’s profound influence on his career since joining Liverpool in 2008, crediting Gerrard’s mentorship and leadership as pivotal to his development. Gerrard, set to leave Liverpool for LA Galaxy after the season, aims to conclude his tenure by winning the FA Cup, with a semi-final against Aston Villa and a potential final against Arsenal on his birthday. Skrtel hails Gerrard as one of the world’s best players, synonymous with Liverpool’s identity, while acknowledging the challenge of replacing him, though he believes the club has capable successors if supported properly. Both players return from suspensions for the Villa match, underscoring Gerrard’s enduring legacy and Skrtel’s gratitude for his guidance.

At 75, Jack Nicklaus achieved a hole-in-one during the par-3 contest at Augusta National, delighting the crowd alongside playing partners Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. His ace, the first of his career at Augusta, was part of a record-tying day with five holes-in-one, including two by Camilo Villegas, though the title was ultimately won by Kevin Streelman in a playoff. Nicklaus, a six-time Masters champion and the youngest winner in 1963, humorously noted he had predicted his success earlier that day, while his historic achievement as one of five career grand slam winners was contrasted with Rory McIlroy’s ongoing pursuit of the same accolade.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas as storms brought multiple twister reports, including a confirmed sighting near Goddard and three near Aetna, with CNN's Chad Myers emphasizing the heightened danger of nighttime tornadoes. The storms also impacted Missouri, where a possible tornado in Potosi caused wind damage, flooding, and downed trees, while baseball-sized hail was reported in Farmington. Additional severe weather is forecast for the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, and surrounding regions on Thursday.

An Oklahoma reserve deputy, Robert Bates, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for fatally shooting Eric Harris during an April arrest, claiming he accidentally used his gun instead of a taser. Despite the ongoing case, a judge permitted Bates to vacation in the Bahamas, prompting criticism from Harris’s family, who accused him of indifference. Bates’s lawyers assert the shooting was unintentional and released training records to counter allegations he lacked qualifications, while Harris’s family contends Bates received preferential treatment due to donations and ties to the sheriff. The Tulsa County Sheriff’s Office denies claims of forged training records, and two deputies involved in the arrest were reassigned over safety concerns. A preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2.

Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title fight against champion Jose Aldo in Las Vegas on July 11, having unveiled a new tiger tattoo on his stomach symbolizing his predatory mindset, as he stated, "If you see the tiger, it's too late. You're food." The 26-year-old Irishman, who already has a gorilla tattoo on his chest, criticized Aldo's motivation, claiming the champion lacks his drive to win. Aldo, making his eighth title defense, faced tension with McGregor during a promotional tour in Dublin when McGregor seized his belt and taunted him in front of supporters, highlighting their contentious relationship ahead of the bout.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott faced criticism after quickly drinking a large beer (a "schooner") at a sports event, with anti-drinking campaigners and cultural studies professor Julie Robert accusing him of glorifying binge drinking and reinforcing harmful stereotypes linking masculinity to excessive alcohol consumption. While Abbott's actions were cheered by attendees and defended by Health Minister Sussan Ley, who dismissed concerns by highlighting his fitness, critics argued he should model responsible behavior, noting the event perpetuated a culture prioritizing drinking speed over moderation. The incident also drew comparisons to past political figures and highlighted evolving societal concerns about alcohol-related norms in Australia.

Indiana is experiencing a significant HIV outbreak in Scott County linked to intravenous drug use of the painkiller Opana, with 120 confirmed cases and 10 preliminary positives reported amid a 30-day needle exchange program approved by Governor Mike Pence. Health officials anticipate further increases as testing expands, while Pence faces pressure to extend the program beyond its April 25 deadline, having distributed over 5,000 clean syringes to 86 participants so far. The outbreak, typically limited to five annual cases, has sparked legislative debate over authorizing needle exchanges in high-risk counties, opposed by Pence and some lawmakers who fear enabling drug use, despite evidence linking such programs to harm reduction. Federal funding restrictions and sustainability concerns complicate long-term solutions, as advocates argue the crisis demands expanded public health measures beyond Scott County.

An obsessive Arsenal fan created a detailed exam testing his girlfriend's knowledge of the club, featuring multiple-choice questions, player positions, historical facts, and opinion-based prompts, with her scoring 87% (43.5/50) and avoiding a breakup as a result. Her Twitter post about the test, including her humorous and occasionally inaccurate answers—such as praising Alexis Sánchez's physique and criticizing Eden Hazard—went viral, sparking mixed reactions: some praised her dedication and the boyfriend's creativity, while others criticized the stunt as extreme. Despite struggling with player positions and squad lineups, her creative responses and high score earned approval from fans, though the boyfriend's mock-strict feedback and sarcastic exam instructions highlighted the quiz's playful yet intense nature.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former Medellin Cartel member, faces deportation from the U.S. after working undercover for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for a promised citizenship that was never granted. His cooperation led to high-profile prosecutions, including drug lord Carlos Lehder and ex-Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega, but declining health forced his retirement, leaving him undocumented. Despite pleas for help, the DEA refused assistance, and Toro now lives in legal limbo without access to social security or healthcare, fearing fatal retaliation if deported to Colombia. A former colleague provided $5,000 for medical treatment after the agency denied support, highlighting bureaucratic failures, as Toro insists he "atoned" for his past and demands the citizenship he was assured.

A 14-year-old Indian girl is hospitalized with severe burns after setting herself on fire following an alleged gang rape by five villagers in Uttar Pradesh, with her family urging silence about the attack. The accused have been arrested amid heightened national sensitivity over sexual violence, exacerbated by the recent ban on a documentary about the 2012 Delhi gang rape and murder of Jyoti Singh, which sparked global outrage and legal reforms. Recent vigilante incidents, including mob lynchings of suspected rapists, reflect public frustration over inadequate protections for women, while officials cite concerns about disorder from such protests and media coverage.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal aims to defeat rivals Manchester City in the upcoming derby but will be without striker Robin van Persie and defender Luke Shaw, both deemed unfit despite Van Persie's claims of readiness. With City vulnerable after a recent loss, a United victory could secure third place, avoiding a Champions League qualifier, though Van Gaal emphasizes controlling aggression after their earlier 1-0 defeat to City. Key players like Wayne Rooney, David de Gea, and Radamel Falcao trained ahead of the match, as Van Gaal acknowledged the fans' strong support and expressed confidence in his team's progress, noting that finishing third would exceed pre-season expectations.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested soaring ticket prices by leaving seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their Premier League match at Emirates Stadium, following the league’s £5.14 billion TV rights deal. With tickets starting at £64—among the league’s highest—supporters displayed banners criticizing the cost, including “£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket” and “Football without fans is nothing.” Organizers from fan groups like Arsenal’s Black Scarf Movement and Liverpool’s Spirit of Shankly condemned prices as “extortionate,” warning of alienating working-class fans and losing future generations unless authorities implement tangible reductions. Further protests were planned post-match.

A newborn named Star was diagnosed with biliary atresia, a rare condition causing blocked bile ducts, after her parents noticed persistent jaundice shortly after birth. Despite an initial procedure to unblock the ducts, she required a liver transplant, which her maternal aunt, Shanell Reader, provided by donating part of her liver when neither parent was a suitable match. The transplant, performed in November, was successful, and Star has since recovered, though she will need lifelong monitoring and medication. Her family expressed profound gratitude for the donation, emphasizing the life-saving impact of her aunt’s intervention.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian competed in Audi's football challenge, split into teams of Hazard/Ake versus Remy/Willian. The event featured rounds like close-range shooting into a car boot (won 5-3 by Hazard/Ake), long-range shots into a convertible Audi, and a tennis-style challenge over a £127,000 Audi R8 V10 Plus, where Hazard/Ake extended their lead to 6-0. The final round, requiring long-range shots through a convertible's roof, saw Remy/Willian win, though Willian accidentally smashed a car's wing mirror, prompting a humorous reaction from Remy, before being allowed to drive an Audi as part of the event.

Robert Dellinger, a former Fortune 500 executive, pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault after causing a 2013 highway crash in New Hampshire that killed Amanda Murphy, 24, her fiancé Jason Timmons, 29, and their unborn child. Prosecutors initially claimed Dellinger, who drove his truck into oncoming traffic at over 100 mph, was suicidal, but he denied this during sentencing, asserting he was not suicidal. His defense attributed his actions to Ambien withdrawal, psychiatric medication effects, and multiple sclerosis symptoms. Dellinger faces 12 to 24 years in prison, while his wife characterized him as ethical and grieving, expressing condolences to the victims' families. The crash, which sheared the roof off the couple's SUV, also prompted a wrongful death lawsuit by Murphy's estate, with prosecutors noting Dellinger had argued with his wife over medications before the incident.

Lacey Spears, a woman from Scottsville, Kentucky, was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for the second-degree murder of her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, after poisoning him with salt through his feeding tube, a crime prosecutors attributed to her craving attention by exploiting his purported illnesses. The boy’s father, Chris Hill, publicly condemned Spears on Facebook, expressing hope she would die in prison and criticizing her emotionless demeanor during sentencing, while the judge acknowledged her mental illness but deemed the act "unfathomable in its cruelty." Prosecutors emphasized Spears’ pattern of subjecting her son to unnecessary medical procedures and using his suffering for social media attention, while her defense claimed innocence, blamed hospital negligence, and plans to appeal.

Australia is receiving an updated influenza vaccine delayed by one month to include protection against strains H3N2 and B/Phuket, which caused a surge in flu-related deaths in Europe and the US due to mismatched vaccines. High-risk groups, including the young, elderly, and Indigenous Australians, will receive free government-funded shots starting April 20, while experts urge widespread vaccination to protect vulnerable populations, noting the modified vaccine offers better strain coverage and could reduce mortality compared to the northern hemisphere’s experience.

Abraham Lincoln’s tomb in Springfield, Illinois, faces criticism from *National Geographic* for its "office lobby"-like interior and potential mismanagement, coinciding with the 150th anniversary of his assassination. The site, managed by a state agency threatened by budget cuts and proposed elimination under Governor Bruce Rauner, has reduced hours and staffing due to prior funding reductions, sparking visitor complaints about accessibility. Despite over $2.5 million in recent renovations—including marble, bronze, and lighting upgrades—the tomb’s historical presentation remains contested, with defenders arguing the critique is unfair and the structure physically sound, while supporters worry further cuts could jeopardize its maintenance and public access.

The resurgence of 1990s and 2000s fashion trends, including JNCO's notoriously wide-legged "rave" jeans, has sparked debate, with many dismissing such styles as impractical or outdated. Femail highlights nine retro trends deemed undesirable, contrasting their past popularity with current revivals: bucket hats (worn by Christina Aguilera then, Rihanna now), camouflage print (favored by Destiny's Child earlier, Jourdan Dunn today), extreme styling like double denim (embraced by Britney Spears and Justin Timberlake, continued by Kylie Jenner), Ugg boots (Paris Hilton's staple, still worn by Kristen Bell), ultra-short Daisy Dukes (Jessica Simpson's signature, now Miley Cyrus's), Juicy Couture tracksuits (Britney Spears and Paris Hilton's go-to, revived by Nicki Minaj), colored sunglasses (*NSYNC and Britney's choice, updated by Cara Delevingne and Jenner), corsets as outerwear (Victoria Beckham's Spice Girls era, adapted by Selena Gomez), and harem pants (Kim Kardashian's past preference, sported by Elle Macpherson). While some trends persist through celebrity influence, the article argues these styles largely merit remaining in the past.

The passage highlights several trending stories from the week, including the appearance of four rainbows over New York after heavy rain, captured by a fashion CEO; China's crackdown on hiring exotic dancers for funerals; actor Robert Downey Jr.'s tense interview over personal questions; a viral lip-plumping trend inspired by Kylie Jenner; a 102-year-old woman revisiting her past with filmmakers' help; a controversial prom proposal accused of racism; Ewan McGregor's casting as Lumiere in *Beauty and the Beast*; Johnny Depp's unrecognizable appearance in a new trailer; a pregnancy announcement referencing *Fresh Prince of Bel-Air*; and a military father photobombing his son's photo.

Serena Williams celebrated her 700th career victory at the Miami Open with a giant cake after defeating Sabine Lisicki in three sets (7-6, 1-6, 6-3) to advance to the semi-finals, mirroring Andy Murray’s earlier cake commemoration for his 500th win. Williams’ hopes for a sibling showdown were thwarted when Venus lost to Carla Suarez Navarro, but the world No. 1 secured a semi-final clash against Simona Halep, who defeated Sloane Stephens. The victory also marked Serena’s revenge for a 2013 Wimbledon upset by Lisicki, while the tournament’s festive atmosphere continued with multiple milestone celebrations.

Sabeen Mahmud, a prominent Pakistani advocate for free speech, humanism, and progressive values, was fatally shot by gunmen in Karachi after hosting a discussion at her café, The Second Floor (T2F), on enforced disappearances in Balochistan—a topic suppressed by authorities and media. Known for fostering open dialogue on contentious issues like human rights and women's entrepreneurship, Mahmud faced death threats but persisted in creating spaces for marginalized voices, becoming a national symbol of tolerance. Her murder, which also injured her mother, sparked widespread grief and tributes, underscoring the peril faced by activists challenging censorship and violence in Pakistan. No group claimed responsibility, though her defiance of taboos surrounding Balochistan's insurgency was cited as a likely motive.

Elderly Hindu refugees like 82-year-old Mangu Ram, displaced to Indian Kashmir during the 1947 partition, face decades of statelessness, denied property rights, voting privileges, and government employment due to pre-independence laws and political reluctance to alter the Muslim-majority state's demographic balance. Despite living in India—many never having visited Pakistan—around 100,000 West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) endure intergenerational poverty in slums, excluded from state-run education and jobs, while recent Hindu nationalist BJP electoral gains in Kashmir raise hopes for citizenship normalization. However, persistent regional unrest, activist threats of direct action, and historical governmental inaction over autonomy concerns underscore the tension surrounding their unresolved status.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is considering a £4 million offer from Chelsea, which would initially involve a loan to Vitesse Arnhem, but he prioritizes regular playing time and development. Chelsea’s interest, confirmed by FC Tokyo’s president, aligns with their Japanese sponsorship ties, though manager José Mourinho acknowledges Muto’s potential while avoiding direct comments. Muto’s former coach, Ranko Popovic, praises his intelligence, speed, and confidence, predicting success in Europe, while Muto remains undecided, emphasizing the need to join a team that suits his growth.

Australia is commended for reversing its policy of excluding overseas-based players from national selection, a move that highlights England's outdated approach under Stuart Lancaster, who persists in barring foreign-based talent like Steffon Armitage and Nick Abendanon despite their improved form abroad. The argument emphasizes that World Cup success demands selecting the best available players regardless of location, citing examples such as Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell, whose Toulon performances earned them Wallabies recalls, and contrasting England's stance with football's inclusion of overseas stars. The passage criticizes the Rugby Football Union's restrictions as detrimental to England's competitiveness, noting that players like Armitage and Abendanon have thrived overseas, while questioning the logic of prioritizing domestic loyalty over national team strength, ultimately urging England to adopt Australia's progressive model to avoid World Cup regret.

Open Garden’s FireChat app enables offline messaging via wireless mesh networks, leveraging Apple’s Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) and Android’s Bluetooth to relay messages between devices within 30 feet (9 meters), creating localized nodes for secure, anonymous communication. To address the network’s 200-foot (61-meter) range limit, the company developed Greenstone, an egg-shaped device that acts as a beacon to extend message reach, particularly in areas without connectivity, such as crowded events or transit systems. FireChat, downloaded over five million times, offers "Everyone" and "Nearby" chatrooms for broad or proximity-based messaging, while Greenstone—currently in development—stores up to 1,000 messages, operates on a one-year battery, and works within a 20-foot (6-meter) range to bridge gaps in offline networks, with plans for future commercialization.

Burlesque performer Lillian Bustle advocates reclaiming the word "fat" as a neutral self-descriptor, challenging its association with negativity, and highlights how societal stigma around body size fuels discrimination and harmful beauty ideals. She cites studies showing increased body diversity exposure fosters acceptance, using her performances to celebrate larger bodies positively, and shares how embracing her 240-pound frame through burlesque empowered her, despite initial insecurities. Her 2014 TED Talk, recently posted online, drew widespread praise—including from a teen whose body image it transformed—alongside some backlash, reinforcing her belief that body-positivity movements are gaining cultural ground.

Theo Walcott, often benched this season, joined Arsenal teammates including Mesut Özil, Jack Wilshere, and others for a photoshoot with Lanvin, the club's official tailor since 2013, alongside model Olga Sherer. Despite starting only once since March, Walcott appeared as a late substitute in Arsenal's recent goalless draw against Chelsea and hopes to start against Hull City, while the team prepares for the FA Cup final against Aston Villa at Wembley, where players will wear Lanvin attire.

A collection of over 400 props, puppets, and costumes created by renowned makeup effects artist Rick Baker, valued at approximately $746,100, will be auctioned on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and online via Propstore.com. Highlighted items include the Alien Edgar Bug from *Men in Black* (estimated $40,000+), the Grinch costume from *How the Grinch Stole Christmas* ($8,000), and the Two-Face mask from *Batman Forever* ($1,500), alongside pieces from *Gremlins 2*, *Michael Jackson’s Moonwalker*, and *Planet of the Apes*. The no-reserve auction spans Baker’s 30-year career, offering fans and collectors rare memorabilia, with some lots expected to exceed $40,000.

The family of seven-year-old Carwyn Scott-Howell, a British boy who died in a skiing accident in the French Alps, expressed profound grief, describing him as a daring, outgoing, and determined child whose death left a "vast void" in their hearts. Carwyn, an experienced skier, became separated from his family during their final run in Flaine, entered dense woodland after spotting the resort through trees, and fatally fell 164ft, with police later discovering his body via footprints and sliding marks in the snow. His mother, Ceri, desperately searched for him after realizing he was missing, while investigators confirmed he likely attempted to return to the resort. Tributes highlighted Carwyn’s adventurous spirit, modeled on TV survivalist Bear Grylls, and his joyful nature, with his school and community in Wales mourning his loss and offering condolences.

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed severe anorexia after facing bullying and societal pressure to achieve a "size zero" figure, restricting her intake to around 100 calories daily and hiding food to avoid eating. Her extreme weight loss led to a collapse, requiring hospitalization for a week on a heart monitor due to her body shutting down. Following her recovery with support from eating disorder specialists and mental health services, she now advocates for body positivity and has reached the semi-finals of Miss Teen GB, a competition challenging size-zero stereotypes. The passage underscores the dangers of anorexia, NHS data indicating 725,000 UK eating disorder cases (10% anorexic), and the critical role of early intervention, reflecting Laura’s journey from life-threatening obsession to regained confidence.

Liverpool unveiled their 2015/16 New Balance home kit, featuring a gingham design and Hillsborough disaster tribute, during an event where fans urged Raheem Sterling to remain at the club despite his recent contract rejection and transfer speculation. The £300 million kit deal with New Balance, replacing Warrior, was highlighted as players including Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, and Simon Mignolet presented the strip, with supporters emphasizing their desire for Sterling to stay. Amid discussions of Sterling’s future and his acknowledgment of fan support, the team focused on the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, expressing hopes of winning the trophy as a platform for future success, while honoring departing captain Steven Gerrard’s ambition to end his tenure with a cup final appearance.

Researchers from the University of Manchester have produced the largest high-definition map of dark matter, covering 0.4% of the sky, as part of a five-year Dark Energy Survey (DES) aiming to eventually map 12.5% of the sky in 3D. Created using data from the Dark Energy Camera on the Victor M. Blanco Telescope in Chile, the map detects dark matter's gravitational effects on galaxy shapes, revealing clumped structures that align with theories linking dark matter's concentration to galaxy formation. Though invisible, dark matter constitutes 80-85% of the universe's matter, and its "clumpiness" will help probe dark energy's role in accelerating cosmic expansion. The current map, analyzing 130 million galaxy images via supercomputers, confirms predictions that galaxies form in regions of high dark matter density, with plans to expand observations to further test cosmological models.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign PSV Eindhoven's 21-year-old winger Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal aiming to secure him as a priority summer signing after working with him during the Netherlands' 2014 World Cup campaign. Depay, who scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season and helped PSV win their first Eredivisie title in seven years, is valued higher than Tottenham's rejected £15 million bid last summer, with PSG and another major European club also competing for his signature. Known for his pace, dribbling, and goalscoring from the left wing, Depay has drawn comparisons to Arjen Robben and a young Cristiano Ronaldo, earning praise from scouts and teammates, though his development remains ongoing.

Chelsea secured a 3-1 victory over Manchester City's youth side in a commanding performance at the Academy Stadium, with Tammy Abraham scoring twice in the first half and Dominic Solanke adding a late goal to seal the win, despite Isaac Buckley-Ricketts briefly equalizing for City. Key performances included Abraham's clinical finishing, Solanke's impactful play, and defensive solidity from Chelsea's Fikayo Tomori and Jake Clarke-Salter, while City's Tosin Adarabioyo and Brandon Barker showed promise but struggled to overcome Chelsea's dominance. The result highlighted Chelsea's strength in attack and midfield control, though City's young players demonstrated individual talent despite the loss.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate, stated that while he believes sexual preference is innate, same-sex marriage should not be a constitutional right but instead decided by state legislatures through political debate, not courts. Though personally opposing same-sex marriage as conflicting with his Catholic belief in marriage as between one man and one woman, he affirmed he would attend a same-sex wedding of a loved one, emphasizing respect for personal relationships despite disagreements. He also noted his campaign’s strong financial backing, exceeding $51 million, amid a competitive Republican primary field.

Pablo Mandado, 27, and Ilze Zebolde, 31, abandoned their restaurant jobs in Manchester to embark on an open-ended cycling journey around the world, driven by a dream to explore the planet "a pedal at a time" with no fixed plans or agenda. Starting in London, they have traveled over 7,000 miles (11,131 km) across 16 countries in 356 days, surviving on less than €3 each daily by camping, using hosting platforms like Couchsurfing, and relying on cheap food staples, wild fruits, and occasional dumpster diving. Their route has taken them through Europe, Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia, with plans to continue into Asia, cross the Pacific, and cycle the American continent, documenting their minimalist adventure on their blog, *thecrazytravel*.

A Texas couple is suing photographer James Evans of Premiere Photos, alleging racial slurs like "poor n***** party" were printed on photo booth pictures from their 2012 wedding. The couple, who learned of the slurs months later from the bride's sister, claims Evans refused to apologize and dared them to sue. Represented by attorney Cathy Hale, they filed a lawsuit under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, citing negligence and breach of contract. Evans denies responsibility, arguing no evidence links his company to the incident and disputing claims of mental anguish. Mediation is scheduled, with a trial set for July if unresolved, though the couple primarily seeks an apology rather than financial compensation.

England full-back Mike Brown is adopting a cautious approach to recovering from a concussion sustained during the Six Nations, leaving his return date uncertain after withdrawing from Harlequins' recent match. Highlighting the risks, Northampton's George North has been advised to end his season after four concussions, while Ireland's Johnny Sexton previously faced a 12-week hiatus. Brown, who was knocked unconscious against Italy in February and later pulled out of the Ireland game due to symptoms, stresses the importance of concussion awareness from World Rugby's online modules, which influenced his decision to prioritize long-term health over rushing back. He acknowledges the dangers of repeated head injuries and urges players to take symptoms seriously, reflecting on his own experience and Land Rover's campaign promoting grassroots rugby values.

A decline in sexual activity among British couples, dropping from five times monthly in 1990 to three times currently, has been linked by Professor David Spiegelhalter of Cambridge University to increased smartphone use and technological connectivity. His research highlights how blurred boundaries between work and personal life, constant email checking, and competing time demands reduce opportunities for intimacy, with researcher Catherine Mercer noting sex often becomes a lower priority due to persistent digital distractions.

Tibetan Mastiffs, once prized in China as status symbols fetching prices up to £1.2 million, have seen demand collapse due to the government’s anti-corruption campaign, which curtailed their use as bribes, and urban bans on large dogs exceeding 50kg. This decline has led to mass abandonment, with many dogs being sent to slaughterhouses for meat or leather, as revealed by recent rescues of emaciated, injured, and dead mastiffs en route to abattoirs. Overbreeding for profit degraded the breed’s quality, creating a surplus of unsellable dogs, while rapid urbanization highlighted their unsuitability for city living, accelerating their fall from luxury pets to neglected animals facing cruel exploitation.

A survey of 600 women near Paris revealed that every respondent had experienced sexual harassment or assault on public transport, with half first harassed before age 18. The report highlighted that such incidents, ranging from verbal abuse to physical attacks, often go unreported, leading women to alter their daily routines to avoid confrontation, thereby restricting their freedom and excluding them from public spaces. Six in ten women feared attack on transit compared to three in ten men. The findings prompted calls for a campaign to combat sexist behavior on public transport, with officials emphasizing the need to educate women about their rights, challenge impunity for perpetrators, and raise awareness among bystanders.

Direct Line is hosting a competition called #everydayfix, where designers created prototypes to address common daily stresses identified in a survey of 2,000 people. The top concerns included sleep disruption, lost keys, and phone battery depletion. Three shortlisted solutions include "Snooze," an alarm clock that silences phone notifications; "Forget Me Lock," a key-attached device indicating door lock status via color-coded signals; and "Nipper," a portable charger using household batteries. The public votes via Twitter retweets, with the winning product funded through Kickstarter. Additional prototypes not selected featured innovations like a helmet with bone-conduction directions and a parking space-saving device, though these were excluded from the final shortlist.

Northumbria's Police and Crime Commissioner, Vera Baird, faces a Ministry of Justice investigation for allocating over £500,000 in public funds to *Victims First Northumbria*, a charity she co-directs with Chief Constable Sue Sim, amid allegations of conflicts of interest. Critics, including Home Affairs Committee chair Keith Vaz, condemn the decision as "inappropriate" and liken the force's internal dynamics to a "soap opera," citing concerns over transparency and Sim's prior bullying allegations. The MoJ will assess whether conflict-of-interest rules were breached, while Baird defends the funding as procedurally compliant, praising her collaboration with Sim, who is retiring in June.

Three individuals were imprisoned, including ringleader Corry "Corey" Campbell (sentenced to 20 years) and his girlfriend Sandra Ng (23 months), while two others await sentencing for their roles in a 2014 assault on Greg Valecce, 53. The victim was held captive for 42 hours in a Philadelphia basement, beaten, tied to a chair, and forcibly tattooed with offensive images—including swastikas, racial slurs, and explicit drawings—after Campbell falsely accused him of harming his cat and stealing. Accomplices Carl Halin (also sentenced to 20 years) and others participated in the abuse, which was filmed and involved physical torture, resulting in Valecce suffering broken ribs, wrists, and facial fractures. Police recovered tattoo equipment, drugs, and stolen items from the scene, and Valecce later had the tattoos removed but reported lasting psychological trauma. All pleaded guilty to charges including aggravated assault and false imprisonment.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign PSV Eindhoven's 21-year-old winger Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal aiming to secure him as a priority summer signing after working with the player during the Netherlands' 2014 World Cup campaign. Depay, who has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season and helped PSV win their first Eredivisie title in seven years, is valued higher than Tottenham's rejected £15 million bid last summer, with PSG and another major European club also competing for his signature. Known for his pace, dribbling, and goalscoring from the left wing, Depay has drawn comparisons to Arjen Robben and a young Cristiano Ronaldo, though PSV's manager Phillip Cocu cautions that his full potential remains to be seen.
